utterances: At the crossing, as Eric said, there was widespread looting.
There was a lot of shooting.
About hundreds of Fatah supporters also went to the crossing and tried to convince Israel to let them cross from Gaza into Israel on their way to the West Bank.
Israel said it was allowing this on a case-by-case basis.
Reports are that about 150 Fatah officials from Gaza, some of them with their families, were allowed to cross and many of them did reach Ramallah.
Other Fatah people in Gaza say they're really quite afraid of what could happen to them.
NPR's Linda Gradstein in Jerusalem.
Thank you.
Thank you, Debbie.
From NPR News, this is ALL THINGS CONSIDERED.
I'm Melissa Block.
And I'm Robert Siegel.
The Democratic presidential race is in high gear in South Carolina today.
Senators Hillary Clinton and Barack Obama, former Senator John Edwards, among others are campaigning in the state and they all converge at a certain fish fry.
Not just any fish fry this one's hosted by Congressman Jim Clyburn of South Carolina.
He is the House Democratic whip that makes him the third-most powerful person in the House and he is the ranking African-American.
Congressman Clyburn is sure to be an influential man in the state's early primary.
Last night at South Carolina State University, the Democrats held their first formal televised debate and today they're holding independently town meetings in different parts of South Carolina.
NPR's political correspondent Mara Liasson is in Greenville, South Carolina, and joins us.
Welcome, Mara.
Hello, Robert.
You spent some of today at a Hillary Clinton event.
Tell us about that and Mrs. Clinton's standing in South Carolina right about now.
Well, in the polls, Mrs. Clinton is running first but of course polls at this early stage mean absolutely nothing, at least we keep telling ourselves that as we obsess over them.
But she got an incredibly warm reception at this town meeting.
One man stood up and said: We in South Carolina love you and your husband, South Carolina needs jobs and you are the answer besides God.
So, she got a very warm reception.

She also reprised some of what she clearly considers to be her greatest hits from last night's debate especially the answer she gave to the question of what she would do if two American cities were hit by al-Qaeda, and it was a question that she feels showcases her ability to be commander in chief.

She said as a president I would retaliate, as swiftly and as prudent, you know, it is the job of the president to protect and defend us, and she clearly is running even in this primary season with the general election campaign in mind.
Now, about half of South Carolina's Democratic voters are black.
What does that mean for Barack Obama and what is he doing in the state today?
Well, I think what it means is this is going to be a state where he's expecting to do very well.
His campaign advisers say flatly, we are going to win South Carolina, and every independent observer I've talked to say that he is going to do very well here.
He's working hard here.
I think this is a must win state for him.
South Carolina traditionally has not been a launching pad.
It is the fourth of the early primary and caucus state that comes after Nevada, Iowa and New Hampshire, but it is a validator.
If you can win one of the earlier states and win in South Carolina, you're off to a pretty good start.
But it's also going to be a big test for Barack Obama as to how he can excite and energize African-American voters, how he can boost a black turnout here.
So he is campaigning hard here and he's in Charleston today holding another town meeting.
Well, tell us about Congressman Clyburn's fish fry.
Congressman Clyburn's fish fry is the political event of the year.
Every four years, he holds this fish fry on the same night of the Democratic State Party's Jefferson-Jackson Day Dinner, and it's a free event.
It's for people who can't afford the $100 price of the JJ Dinner.

They get to go to a parking garage in Columbia where they have one menu item -and one menu item only - and that is fried whiting on wonder bread with ketchup and mustard and lots of drinks and great music, and it is an absolute required stop for every presidential candidate.
They're going to meet people but also to pay homage to Jim Clyburn, who's a very important man in this state, and everyone will be there and it's a big, loud, noisy, fun event.
Now, we should just add the proviso here that while South Carolina will be the only one of those four early states in the presidential process with a significant African-American population.
South Carolina is a state which in general elections has not gone for a Democrat in eons.
We turn now from the economy to politics, which actually isn't much of a turn, because John McCain and Barack Obama have been talking about nothing but the economy this week.
Joining us once again is David Brooks of the New York Times, here in the studio, and E.
J.
Dionne of the Washington Post joins us from Grand Rapids, Michigan.
Welcome to both of you.
Good to be here.
Mr. E.
J.
DIONNE (Washington Post): Good to be with you.
What a week.
(Soundbite of laughter)

You know, with people worried about their home values and the overall strength of the economy, the candidates were forced to really sharpen their economic message and also sharpen their attacks on each other.
I'm curious to hear from both of you an assessment of how they've done this week.
Well, I guess I'll start.
I was infuriated through much of the week.
I thought both of them were absolutely moronic or absolutely terrible, behaved, to a complicated situation, in a childish way.
McCain seemed to have no grasp of what the problem was, except that there were a lot of evil people on Wall Street who had to be punished.
And Obama seemed to have no grasp what the problem was, except where it must be George Bush's fault.
And so, I thought their initial reactions were absolutely just childish.
Today, they've done a little better.
Obama and McCain have both released statements, and they were not - they didn't get very far, but I thought they rose to the level of mediocrity.
And so, they said things were serious.
They treated it like a serious situation.
They treated it both like a complex situation.
Both of their ways forward were very vague, but at least they treated us as voters as mature adults who could understand this complex situation that needs a little more than childish soundbites.
Hey, E.
J., David is trying hard not to pound his fist on the table here, he's so angry.
(Soundbite of laughter)
What did you think about the performance this week?
Well, you know what?
I think there are two things that happened this week that are very important.
The first is the large story, which is, you might say, the era of free-market arrogance or Wall Street superiority is over.
I was thinking this morning, Ronald Reagan's famous line, government isn't the solution.
Government is - to our problem.
Government is the problem.
And now the market is the problem, and the government was the only solution we had.
And so, I think there is this very large change in the economic dialogue that has made life particularly difficult for McCain.

And on the McCain side, I think it was just very odd to hear McCain imitating John Edwards' populist rhetoric or Al Gore's 2000 rhetoric in flat contradiction to so much of his anti-regulatory rhetoric in the past.
John McCain as Huey Long, just to extend the metaphor, just doesn't work.
On the Obama side, I think that Obama has not had a crisp message on the economy for awhile, and that this week really helped him out.
I think that he's finally started to figure out at least some economic message.
He was stronger this week.
I don't think he was quite as moronic as David suggested, but I do think he's going to have to get stronger still for that debate.
It's sort of partial crispness now.
David, when Obama appeared today with his economic team, it was an interesting tableau.
You had several former Treasury secretaries, including Goldman Sachs' Chairman Bob Rubin.
You had Warren Buffet sitting down to talk to him.
For a candidate who has - who has been all about change, cloaked himself with change throughout this campaign, he's reaching back to the past for his economic advice.
I think Gene Sperling from the Clinton administration, and for an old elitist like me, this was good news.
And I think this is the nature of the man.
He has billed himself as a change agent, and in some respects, he obviously is.
But I think the core - and friends of Obama's have told me this - the core of the man, he's a cautious person.
And I think he has true respect for the people who've been around and have cautious, sober advice.
And the people who surrounded him today were extremely the Rubenesque, centrist, moderate core of the Democratic Party.
And I essentially think that's the way he'd govern.
I think we have two candidates who know relatively little about economics and Wall Street.
But I think we have both, and I think - my hope at the end of the day, they will go to sober people.
And Obama showed that today.
He surrounded himself with the Democratic establishment.
E.
J., you're in Michigan right now, and in your column today, you write about the challenges that Obama faces there, obviously a state where the economic news has been particularly grim of late.
I'm curious.
Does this economic crisis change the electoral map?
I think the economic crisis on balance has tilted the election more Obama's way than it was last week.
I think you're seeing that in this week's polls, and there are a lot of factors there.
Palin's popularity is wearing off a little bit.
The McCain's campaign has really been quite mendacious, and I think that's becoming clear.
But I think the larger change is the economy, and I think this shift does help Obama in Michigan.
He does not want Michigan to be about Reagan Democratic issues, social issues, or race out in the white suburbs.
He wants it to be about economics.
And as a friend of mine put it this morning, when people hear the word depression, they seem to have a genetic tendency to go back to the Democrats, and I think that's true in Michigan.
Terms of this meeting with Obama, I think that one of the paradoxes is that in a moment like this, people desperately want change because the economy is in trouble.
But they also want stability in a sense that somebody who took over would be stable.

And so, Obama has to send both messages at the same time that it is about change, but that he knows all the smart, traditional people and will sort of change things from the inside out, without turning them upside down.
David, the anger that you spoke of was evident in a column that you wrote earlier this week and I want to ask you about this.
It focused on Sarah Palin and concerns about her experience that some conservative commentators are raising, including yourself.
How much of a factor will that be - her readiness - when voters actually walk into the polling place in November?
Butler started playing piano as a child in a New Orleans housing project.
He went on to study at the Louisiana State School for the Blind, learning classical piano scores in Braille.
Oh, good, I'd love to hear it twice.
No, you're not going to hear it twice.
Well, I hesitate to think that vice presidents make a great deal of difference.
Nonetheless, I think what we've done is we've entered a phase because of this economic crisis where the electorate is going to shift.
They're going to be more nervous about the future.
They're going to want change.
But because of the riskiness in the economy, they're going to want maturity in the next president.
And I think when they look at Sarah Palin next to the complexity of this economic crisis, well, there's a contrast there, isn't there?
And they may think that about Barack Obama, too, by the way.
The dynamics that this will create, to me, are extremely interesting.
I think the economic turmoil will increase the desire for change.
No question about that.
And I do think that helps Obama.
But in times of economic crisis, people retreat to safety.
And to me, the race over the next five weeks will become much more changed with safety.
And I think Obama, in the first day, at least today, has thread that needle reasonably well with personifying change, but by surrounding himself with Buffet and Ruben, who are safe individuals.
And McCain has done, I think, less well with his economic plan, which is vague, but hasn't - he hasn't projected stability and safety over the last week.
Yes or no question very quickly to each of you.
The candidates, obviously this week were focused on the turmoil on Wall Street.

But did they do a good enough job of calming the jitters on Main Street, where people are concerned about their pensions, people are concerned about writing their college tuition check - did they do a good enough job doing that, David?
I would say - I would give a slight edge to Obama on that right now.
